awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Structure-Property Relationships of Non-Fullerene Acceptors for Photovoltaic Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Fayetteville State University has potential broader impacts in a number of areas. The goal of the project is to obtain a better understanding of the thermal, optical, and electronic properties of organic semiconductors. Such understanding will provide guidelines for the design, synthesis and fabrication of highly efficient polymer solar cells to the renewable energy industry. Undergraduate students will gain research experiences and the research will be integrated in an undergraduate course.

The research goals of the project are to (1) investigate the conditions for optimum solar cell coverage, (2) examine the impact of polymer conformation, molecular architecture of acceptors, and nano-morphology on charge generation, (3) understand the interface electronic properties in connection with charge separation dynamics, and (4) determine the importance of charge and thermal transport in non-fullerene polymer solar cells. Optical spectroscopy, charge transport measurements and morphological and structural characterizations will be used for completion of the project.  The findings from this research will provide future directions for polymer and non-fullerene acceptor synthesis and the design of high efficiency organic electronic devices for solar cell applications. Investigation and improvement of these structures not only furthers our understanding of photophysical processes in organic semiconductors, but also impacts the world by providing inexpensive, renewable, green energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit of the project

Charge generation and transport are the key parameters that determine the performance of a wide range of electronic devices including solar cells. In this work, we focused on how the chemical structure of donors and acceptors and materials processing influence charge generation and the device functionality in polymer solar cells. Firstly, we studied the effect of additives on aggregation and charge generation in polymer blend. Secondly, we studied the impact of charge transport layer on morphology and charge transport in polymer non fullerene blend. We also studied the effect of donor polymer side chain on morphology and optical and thermal properties of polymer non fullerene blends.  Furthermore, we investigated the impact of dipole moment and molecular architecture of non-fullerene acceptors on optical properties. The following findings were revealed from the project.

1. Changes in aggregation, exciton delocalization, electron transfer efficiency from donor to acceptor, and charge generation were observed when additive was added to the pristine blend solution. Our work indicates that the molecular conformation and aggregation changes caused by the additive can result in the contrast in the device performance of fullerene-based polymer solar cells.

2. More distinct phase separated domains are observed in annealed polymer non fullerene blended films compared to non-annealed one indicating the improvement in nanomorphology.

3. Our results indicate that the charge transport layer underneath the active layer impacts the nanomorphology and charge transport in the polymer non fullerene blend. The enhancement of current was observed in MXene-based polymer solar cells.

4. Polymer blend with donor polymer having aliphatic side chain has smooth phase separation with inter-penetrating mesh-like networks compared with donor polymer of oligoethylene glycol side chain.

5. H- like copolymer film showed the longer excited state lifetime, better packing and more oriented crystals relative to J-like one.

6. Exciton splitting is more efficient in galvinoxyl radical added polymer non fullerene blend compared to the pristine blend.

Broader impacts of the project

The project was focused to promote STEM education by engaging underrepresented undergraduate students in research and scholarly activities. Twenty students were involved in the research project. Out of 20, sixteen were female, ten were African American, one was Hispanic and four were high school students. They were trained in sample preparation, sample characterization, data analysis, poster and oral presentation, and manuscript writing. Eight undergraduate students and two high school students co-authored the published journals. Nine students presented their research work at conferences and symposia. To the date, four undergraduate students are pursing graduate study at prestigious universities, two high school students got admission to University of North Carolina residential high school and other two high school students received full ride scholarship and got enrolled in prestigious universities, and four students completed summer internships at National Labs and research-intensive universities.  Glove box and spin coater purchased from this grant were also used by other researchers which established a collaboration with other faculty within the department and university. The project helped secure other fundings which helped adding other physical resources including lifetime spectrometer, differential scanning calorimeter etc. New characterization tools were also added to the Instrumental Analysis Laboratory course to integrate research in teaching. Overall, the project provided a unique opportunity for undergraduate and high school students to be involved in cutting-edge research in the field of polymer solar cells, academic success of students through research and publications, and increased the research capacity of the university.  Our work provided better understanding of thermal, optical, and electronic properties of organic semiconductors which will help design and fabricate efficient polymer solar cells.

The product of the project includes ten peer reviewed publications and more than twenty scholarly presentations at conferences, workshops and symposia.


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Bhoj R Gautam
